messages.subject: Re: Kaishaku under the rain
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Bob, Yes. www.johnstuart.biz  It started as a place to exhibit some pieces for discussion and then grew after that. I am not a computer whiz, for sure, but,
messages.messageBody:
Hi Bob, Yes. www.johnstuart.biz It started as a place to exhibit
some pieces for discussion and then grew after that. I am not a
computer whiz, for sure, but, it is fun, sometimes!!!!! John

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Bob Elder <toyama1_2000@...>
wrote:
>
> Sorry you guys for the personal email, but....do you
> have a web site? Thanks! Bob
>
> --- excelsiorilluminati <excelsiorilluminati@...>
> wrote:
>
> > Hi Bob, I try!! to understand Hyo Ho Niten Ichi Ryu.
> > John
> >
> > --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Bob Elder
> > <toyama1_2000@>
> > wrote:
> > >
> > > What do you practice? B E
> > >
> > > --- excelsiorilluminati <excelsiorilluminati@>
> > > wrote:
> > >
> > > > Hi Bob, Just my experience. I have less control
> > with
> > > > one hand when
> > > > practising mengiri. John
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Bob Elder
> > > > <toyama1_2000@>
> > > > wrote:
> > > > >
> > > > > Not sure what type of cutting you do but in my
> > > > > experience cutting with one hand is a lot less
> > > > likely
> > > > > to roll than with two. FWIW. Bob Elder
> > > > > still trying to figure it all out...
> > > > > --- excelsiorilluminati <excelsiorilluminati@>
> > > > > wrote:
> > > > >
> > > > > > Hi Guys, I just followed this thread on both
> > > > Yahoo
> > > > > > forums and found
> > > > > > it interesting and humourous. There was a
> > lot of
> > > > > > testing done at the
> > > > > > execution grounds and it seems probable that
> > a
> > > > sword
> > > > > > of particularly
> > > > > > heavy weight and special construction would
> > be
> > > > used
> > > > > > to test ones
> > > > > > abilities in a one handed stroke. I would
> > hate
> > > > to be
> > > > > > the prisoner,
> > > > > > as, the one handed grip has a tendency to
> > turn
> > > > in
> > > > > > the cut. Most
> > > > > > executions being done by low ranking bushi.
> > I do
> > > > not
> > > > > > think that it
> > > > > > would be used because of the rain though.
> > There
> > > > > > would be plenty of
> > > > > > attendants to assist with the restraints,
> > > > guarding,
> > > > > > official
> > > > > > recorders and their attendants that someone
> > > > could
> > > > > > hold an umbrella or
> > > > > > construct cover. The thought of the
> > executioner
> > > > > > calling "Bring the
> > > > > > special umbrella holding one handed in the
> > rain
> > > > > > sword" is what
> > > > > > brought a smile to my face. John
> > > > > >
> > > > > >
> > > > > >
> > > > > >
> > > > > >
> > > > > >
> > > > > >
> > > > > > --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Richard
> > > > Turner
> > > > > > <ikkanshi@>
> > > > > >
> > > > > > wrote:
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > or a side kick ( assistant ) would hold
> > the
> > > > > > umbrella
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > Richard
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > Tom Helm wrote:
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > Maximo -
> > > > > > > > This idea I think comes from the popular
> > > > comic
> > > > > > Kubi-kiri Asaemon,
> > > > > > > > all about the Shoguns executioner. I
> > believe
> > > > > > that if the
> > > > > > executioner
> > > > > > > > needed one hand to hold the umbrella, he
> > > > would
> > > > > > simply use his
> > > > > > > > wakizashi...
> > > > > > > > -t
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > On Nov 2, 2006, at 5:57 AM, Maximo
> > wrote:
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > > Hello to every one,
> > > > > > > > > I want to know if anyone ear about a
> > > > special
> > > > > > executioners blade
> > > > > > to
> > > > > > > > > be used
> > > > > > > > > under the rain; short, very curved,
> > meant
> > > > to
> > > > > > be used with only
> > > > > > one
> > > > > > > > > hand
> > > > > > > > > while the other hand held the
> > umbrella.
> > > > > > > > > Does any one know something about this
> > > > special
> > > > > > sword?
> > > > > > > > > Thank in advance
> > > > > > > > > Máximo
> > > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > > PS. Again, Sorry for those copied more
> > > > than
> > > > > > one time.
> > > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > > Máximo D. Marchionni
> > > > > > > > > www.maximom. com.ar
> > > > > > > > > Maximo@maximom. com.ar
> > > > > > <mailto:Maximo%40maximom.com.ar>
> > > > > > > > >

> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > >
> > > > >
> > > >

messages.subject: need BOOK Help- 1 paage of Toso Kinko Jiten
messages.msgSnippet: Hi All, I was wondering if anyone had a copy of the Toso Kinko Jiten by Wakayama Takeshi?  I am looking for a copy of page 500 the lower section for a smith
messages.messageBody:
Hi All,

I was wondering if anyone had a copy of the Toso Kinko
Jiten by Wakayama Takeshi? I am looking for a copy of
page 500 the lower section for a smith named (Arai)
NORIMASA, I believe there are 4 entries. Any help
would be much appreciated.

Thanks,
Ken



____________________________________________________________________________________
Cheap talk?
Check out Yahoo! Messenger's low PC-to-Phone call rates.
http://voice.yahoo.com

Sorry you guys for the personal email, but....do you
have a web site? Thanks! Bob

messages.subject: Re: Kaishaku under the rain
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Bob, I try!! to understand Hyo Ho Niten Ichi Ryu. John
messages.messageBody:
Hi Bob, I try!! to understand Hyo Ho Niten Ichi Ryu. John

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Bob Elder <toyama1_2000@...>
wrote:
>
> What do you practice? B E
>
> --- excelsiorilluminati <excelsiorilluminati@...>
> wrote:
>

> > one hand when

> > wrote:
> > >
> > > Not sure what type of cutting you do but in my
> > > experience cutting with one hand is a lot less
> > likely
> > > to roll than with two. FWIW. Bob Elder
> > > still trying to figure it all out...
> > > --- excelsiorilluminati <excelsiorilluminati@>
> > > wrote:
> > >
> > > > Hi Guys, I just followed this thread on both
> > Yahoo
> > > > forums and found
> > > > it interesting and humourous. There was a lot of
> > > > testing done at the
> > > > execution grounds and it seems probable that a
> > sword
> > > > of particularly
> > > > heavy weight and special construction would be
> > used
> > > > to test ones
> > > > abilities in a one handed stroke. I would hate
> > to be
> > > > the prisoner,
> > > > as, the one handed grip has a tendency to turn
> > in
> > > > the cut. Most
> > > > executions being done by low ranking bushi. I do
> > not
> > > > think that it
> > > > would be used because of the rain though. There
> > > > would be plenty of
> > > > attendants to assist with the restraints,
> > guarding,
> > > > official
> > > > recorders and their attendants that someone
> > could
> > > > hold an umbrella or
> > > > construct cover. The thought of the executioner
> > > > calling "Bring the
> > > > special umbrella holding one handed in the rain
> > > > sword" is what
> > > > brought a smile to my face. John
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >

messages.subject: Re: Kaishaku under the rain
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Bob, Just my experience. I have less control with one hand when practising mengiri. John
messages.messageBody:
Hi Bob, Just my experience. I have less control with one hand when
practising mengiri. John


--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Bob Elder <toyama1_2000@...>
wrote:
>
> Not sure what type of cutting you do but in my
> experience cutting with one hand is a lot less likely
> to roll than with two. FWIW. Bob Elder
> still trying to figure it all out...
> --- excelsiorilluminati <excelsiorilluminati@...>
> wrote:
>
> > Hi Guys, I just followed this thread on both Yahoo
> > forums and found
> > it interesting and humourous. There was a lot of
> > testing done at the
> > execution grounds and it seems probable that a sword
> > of particularly
> > heavy weight and special construction would be used
> > to test ones
> > abilities in a one handed stroke. I would hate to be
> > the prisoner,
> > as, the one handed grip has a tendency to turn in
> > the cut. Most
> > executions being done by low ranking bushi. I do not
> > think that it
> > would be used because of the rain though. There
> > would be plenty of
> > attendants to assist with the restraints, guarding,
> > official
> > recorders and their attendants that someone could
> > hold an umbrella or
> > construct cover. The thought of the executioner
> > calling "Bring the
> > special umbrella holding one handed in the rain
> > sword" is what
> > brought a smile to my face. John
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Richard Turner
> > <ikkanshi@>
> >
> > wrote:
> > >
> > > or a side kick ( assistant ) would hold the
> > umbrella
> > >
> > > Richard
> > >
> > > Tom Helm wrote:
> > > >
> > > > Maximo -
> > > > This idea I think comes from the popular comic
> > Kubi-kiri Asaemon,
> > > > all about the Shoguns executioner. I believe
> > that if the
> > executioner
> > > > needed one hand to hold the umbrella, he would
> > simply use his
> > > > wakizashi...
> > > > -t
> > > >
> > > > On Nov 2, 2006, at 5:57 AM, Maximo wrote:
> > > >
> > > > > Hello to every one,
> > > > > I want to know if anyone ear about a special
> > executioners blade
> > to
> > > > > be used
> > > > > under the rain; short, very curved, meant to
> > be used with only
> > one

messages.messageBody:

experience cutting with one hand is a lot less likely
to roll than with two. FWIW. Bob Elder
still trying to figure it all out...

messages.subject: Re: Kaishaku under the rain
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Guys, I just followed this thread on both Yahoo forums and found it interesting and humourous. There was a lot of testing done at the execution grounds and
messages.messageBody:
Hi Guys, I just followed this thread on both Yahoo forums and found
it interesting and humourous. There was a lot of testing done at the
execution grounds and it seems probable that a sword of particularly
heavy weight and special construction would be used to test ones
abilities in a one handed stroke. I would hate to be the prisoner,
as, the one handed grip has a tendency to turn in the cut. Most
executions being done by low ranking bushi. I do not think that it
would be used because of the rain though. There would be plenty of
attendants to assist with the restraints, guarding, official
recorders and their attendants that someone could hold an umbrella or
construct cover. The thought of the executioner calling "Bring the
special umbrella holding one handed in the rain sword" is what
brought a smile to my face. John







--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Richard Turner <ikkanshi@...>

wrote:
>
> or a side kick ( assistant ) would hold the umbrella
>

This idea I think comes from the popular comic Kubi-kiri Asaemon,
all about the Shoguns executioner. I believe that if the executioner
needed one hand to hold the umbrella, he would simply use his
wakizashi...
-t

messages.msgSnippet: i don t recall this show but it doesn t look like i could find any info on the sword . are you sure it was a one handed sword it would be very difficult to
messages.messageBody:
i don't recall this show but it doesn't look like i could find any info on the sword . are you sure it was a one handed sword it would be very difficult to behead some one with a one handed sword.

frkirk <kirk-becky@...> wrote: Hi Maximo
I do recall seeing something on this on a History Channel show on
the samurai. I believe our very own Moses was showing one such
sword and discussing excatly your point- that it was meant to be
used to behead someone with one hand so that the other had could
hold an umbrella.
Anyone else recall the show?

messages.messageBody:
Hi Maximo
I do recall seeing something on this on a History Channel show on
the samurai. I believe our very own Moses was showing one such
sword and discussing excatly your point- that it was meant to be
used to behead someone with one hand so that the other had could
hold an umbrella.
Anyone else recall the show?

messages.subject: Kaishaku under the rain
messages.msgSnippet: Hello to every one, I want to know if anyone ear about a special executioners blade to be used under the rain; short, very curved, meant to be used with only
messages.messageBody:
Hello to every one,
I want to know if anyone ear about a special executioners blade to be used
under the rain; short, very curved, meant to be used with only one hand
while the other hand held the umbrella.
Does any one know something about this special sword?
Thank in advance
Máximo

PS. Again, Sorry for those copied more than one time.

Máximo D. Marchionni
www.maximom.com.ar
Maximo@...
